ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Not the most interesting content, but possible to learn it with the help of good lectures. I think that a different logic course should count towards the logic requirement for grad students - some of the logics that we often see in journal articles, for example. I will probably never use this logic again, but if the course had been about modal logic instead, I probably would have been able to use it my other classes.
Not unless it is a requirement.
A tough course that teaches you how to think systematically and clearly. Take it if you're hardworking and think that these things are valuable.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Did not really contribute to my research, but the problems were sometimes fun.

The course contributed almost not at all to my research interests.I would very, very, very much have preferred to take a course in "logic for philosophy" (such as the one outlined in Ted Sider's books) rather than a course in mathematical logic in order to fulfill my logic requirement. I'd like to be able to understand the modal logic that gets thrown around in journal articles!
I think it helped me to think more systematically and clearly
